title: Krka monastery
text:
The Krka Monastery (; ) is a <a href="Serbian%20Orthodox">Serbian Orthodox</a> <a href="monastery">monastery</a> dedicated to the <a href="Archangel%20Michael">Archangel Michael</a>, located near the river <a href="Krka%20%28Croatia%29">Krka</a>, 3 km east of <a href="Kistanje">Kistanje</a>, in central <a href="Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a>, <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>. It is the best known monastery of the Serbian Orthodox Church in Croatia and it is officially protected as part of the <a href="Krka%20National%20Park">Krka National Park</a>.
History.
The oldest extant mention of the monastery was in 1345, when it is listed as an endowment of princess <a href="Jelena%20Nemanji%C4%87%20%C5%A0ubi%C4%87">Jelena Nemanjić Šubić</a>, half-sister of the <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a>n <a href="emperor">emperor</a> <a href="Stefan%20Du%C5%A1an">Dušan</a> and wife of <a href="Mladen%20III%20%C5%A0ubi%C4%87%20Bribirski">Mladen III Šubić Bribirski</a>, Croatian duke of <a href="Skradin">Skradin</a> and <a href="Bribir%20%28Skradin%29">Bribir</a>. The monastery was built on top of a <a href="Ancient%20Rome">Roman</a> site, and Roman burial <a href="catacombs">catacombs</a> exist beneath a part of the church.
The current church of St. <a href="Archangel">Archangel</a> was erected in 1422 on the location of an earlier <a href="Gothic%20architecture">Gothic</a> structure. <a href="Ottoman%20Turks">Ottoman Turks</a> devastated the church around 1530 but it was restored on several occasions. Other monastery buildings (18th–19th century), the church, and the belfry are situated around a rectangular <a href="cloister">cloister</a> with arcades.
In mid-17th century monks were forced to flee from the <a href="Ottomans">Ottomans</a> and found shelter in <a href="Zadar">Zadar</a>, where pope <a href="Innocent%20X">Innocent X</a> in 1655 gave them two churches, that had previously been in possession of <a href="Franciscans%23Third%20Order%20Regular">Franciscans of the Third Order</a>, named "Glagolitians" ("glagoljaši") . In a subsequent agreement with the Franciscans, the monks declared that they "live in the service of the <a href="Greek%20Orthodox%20Church">Greek Church</a>, the old illyrian language."
After <a href="Operation%20Storm">Operation Storm</a> in 1995 the monastery was looted, but not significantly, as it was protected by the <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>n authorities, abandoned, and the seminary shut down and relocated to <a href="Div%C4%8Dibare">Divčibare</a> and, later, <a href="Fo%C4%8Da">Foča</a>. The monks returned in 1998, however, and the seminary reopened in 2001.
Architectural features.
The <a href="belltower">belltower</a> of this monastery was built in the <a href="Romanesque%20architecture">Romanesque style</a>. The complex also includes a chapel of <a href="Saint%20Sava">Saint Sava</a> built in the 19th century, under the tutelage of the <a href="Serbian%20Orthodox">Serbian Orthodox</a> <a href="Bishop">Bishop</a> of <a href="Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a> Stefan Knežević, as well as a new building of the seminary and an additional dormitory building. The monastery has its <a href="archives">archives</a> and a <a href="library">library</a> with a variety of ancient books and valuable items from the 16th to the 20th century, a collection of wooden <a href="icon">icon</a>s (<a href="St.%20John%20the%20Baptist">St. John the Baptist</a> from the 14th or 15th century, work by the so-called "Master of the Tkon Crucifix"), <a href="silver">silver</a>ware and <a href="embroideries">embroideries</a>.
